Tengo una gata (hembra) atigrada de color naranja y un gato (macho) atigrado de color gris, la hembra es más vieja y la tenemos desde hace más tiempo que al otro, cuando llegó el gris, era pequeño y la otra gata lo ha cuidado como si fuese su hijo y cada vez el gato gris cambia más su color, cada vez su tono pasa a ser más anaranjado, es como si se estuviese adaptando para parecerse más a la otra gata

Our youngest cat was rescued as a barely weaned kitten. He was the color of powdered chocolate! Been around all colors of cats and he was a first! As he matured into adulthood, his coat began to have strikingly different colors. He likely has some Siamese DNA...shape of his head...temperament AND he has deep deep chocolate points. His body is reddish brown on his back and turns lighter as it gets to his (big) belly and his neck ruff. I have only ever seen one other cat in our area that was similar (likely a parent) same body shape and full coat, but looked completely black. We knew he had crazy chromosomes, but this episode proves that. Luv this channel!🤎
Oh! Thank goodness I'm not losing my mind. 🤭 My black cat's just losing his eumelanin. 🤫

I had a freaky thought once.  I had a cat that died a couple weeks ago at around the age of 20.  But while we had him  I swear he lost most of his markings in the first year or two.  Or maybe it was due to him becoming obese or his hair starting to grey. It certainly makes biological sense. I have a couple biscuit-colored young cats; lightly browned, not tawny. They don't have striped tails or that 'spider' mark on the forehead. Their brother is/was a tuxedo fellow, white with contrasting caramel/cinnamon. Beautiful. Only one tomcat in the area could have been his daddy.
In other mammals, we had a rescue horse whose winter coat was off-white. For a year. The next spring it revealed that she was really a golden palomino. The neighbors asked my dad if we'd gotten a different horse!
Lastly, I had a friend who developed cancer. Her hair was dark blonde and straight until after chemo. It came in medium red and curly. It was quite stunning, stayed that color until she passed. Ah well.

Was anyone else expecting this video to be about Siamese cats, which are known to have their coat colour change depending on the range of ambient temperatures they live in ?  Apparently this is also due to TYRP1, but a version of it that sensitive to temperature.
Wow, this is perfect timing. Two weeks ago Kitten Academy just had a littler with some brown kittens and it made me wonder why brown coated cats are less common than other coat colors.

And here I thought this was going to talk about how the shades of fur on Siamese and other cats with similar colouration is temperature based, so they are basically a walking thermal map of your cat....

This solves the 20 year personal mystery as to why my black cat turned brown the last few days of her life. She hadn't been eating well for a while and gave it up altogether a few days prior to her passing. It all makes sense now!

I love discussing cat coat colors and DNA traits! :D especially since we have 2 sassy torties (all girls, because of it) and calicos (also all girls, cousins of torties). If you ever see a male calico or tortoiseshell, it's extremely genetically rare... and they are probably sterile too. Few things, 1: Don't even JOKE about the black cat luck thing, and 2: Other cats change color in interesting ways.

1: If your cat changes color and gets dark spots on their fur? Make sure they can't lean on your heaters anymore. Seriously, mild singing of the skin can cause fur to change color, even if it doesn't actually burn, and it can be a bad thing for cats, so be careful.

2: If your cat is a Russian Blue... expect them to change color later in life. Every russian blue I've had or known others to have has turned from a rich beautiful grey to a mottled grey and brown-orange in the later half of their lives.
